timeline.subject: Anthoine Grevillon
timeline.details: Substitut of Arches notes Grevillon has been operating 2-3 years with familiar spirits, healing livestock and people. Requests arrest.

timeline.subject: Anthoine Grevillon
timeline.details: First interrogation at le Thillot. Searched and found horn with seeds, three tinplate boxes with red wax and words including 'hogry', white stone (alun nostre dame). Confessed to having 7+ familiar spirits.

timeline.subject: Anthoine Grevillon
timeline.details: Second interrogation at Arches. Now claims he was drunk during previous confession. Confronted by doyen André Ferry. Eventually confesses again to having up to 7 familiars.

timeline.subject: Anthoine Grevillon
timeline.details: Letter received from substitut de Faulcogny en Bourgogne confirming reputation for sorcery and that Nicolas Lambolez died after carrying familiar spirit Grevillon sold him.

timeline.subject: Anthoine Grevillon
timeline.details: Witness Jean Thiebauld testifies about Grevillon's treatment of Delat Godel's wife and elaborate healing rituals.

timeline.subject: Anthoine Grevillon
timeline.details: Questioned about information from Faulcogney; denies some claims, admits to treating patients.

timeline.subject: Anthoine Grevillon
timeline.details: Confronted with witness Jean Thiebauld; mostly agrees to testimony.

timeline.subject: Anthoine Grevillon
timeline.details: PG des Vosges (Dumenil) cites doctors saying use of familiars impossible without pacts; recommends trial as sorcier et magicien.

timeline.subject: Anthoine Grevillon
timeline.details: Interrogation; agrees to using familiars bought from merchants, denies being witch or attending sabbat.

timeline.subject: Anthoine Grevillon
timeline.details: PG des Vosges requests question ordinaire et extraordinaire and pricking for the mark, citing charges of magic and lèse-majesté divine.

timeline.subject: Anthoine Grevillon
timeline.details: Torture with thumbscrews on hands and feet, then racking with wooden triangle under back. Makes limited confessions about demon teaching him remedies.

timeline.subject: Anthoine Grevillon
timeline.details: Surgeon reports pricking for mark; found only one spot with delayed reaction but blood still emerged. Scars from military service at Ostend.

timeline.subject: Anthoine Grevillon
timeline.details: PG des Vosges asks for death sentence with further torture for accomplice names.

timeline.subject: Anthoine Grevillon
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves death sentence but disallows further torture.

timeline.subject: Anthoine Grevillon
timeline.details: Sentence carried out. Trial costs: 107 francs including 79 days imprisonment at 2 gros/day. Paid 8 March 1626.

economic_context.details: Grevillon was an itinerant peddler (mercier) and healer who sold medicines, spices, worm powders, and healing services. He charged for his services (received reistaller et demy for treating Godel's wife). He had left his home region because he was selling nothing there. His trade involved buying and selling merchandise, allegedly using familiar spirits to know the prices merchants had paid.

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a highly unusual case - not a typical witch trial but prosecution of cunning folk/folk healer for using familiar spirits. Grevillon was primarily a traveling peddler-healer who claimed to use small demonic familiars (kept in boxes) to advise him on remedies and business dealings. Key features: (1) No accusations of maleficia in traditional sense - he was a healer, not accused of harming; (2) Extensive testimony about magical healing practices, fern seed collection ritual, urine diagnosis; (3) His familiar spirits were described as fly-sized creatures in boxes that he bought, sold, and fed; (4) Initially retracted confession claiming drunkenness; (5) Under torture made limited confessions about demon teaching remedies; (6) Pricking test essentially negative (surgeon found no true insensible mark); (7) No sabbat attendance, no renunciation of God confessed even under torture; (8) Death sentence based on legal theory that using familiars requires pact with devil; (9) Rich material culture evidence of early modern healing practices; (10) Case involves cross-regional networks (Burgundy, Lorraine, Allemaigne). Trial lasted 79 days, cost 107 francs. This trial is particularly valuable for understanding the fuzzy boundary between acceptable folk healing and prosecutable magic in 17th century Lorraine.
